unnormalised: The Mumbai's Crawford Market saw vegetable prices surge by 20% last week, thanks to the incessant rains. Tomatoes are selling at ₹80/kg, up from ₹60 just a week ago. Onion prices also saw a jump, now retailing at Rs 40/kg. A lot of vendors are saying it's because of transportation issues from Nashik.
normalised: The Mumbai's Crawford Market saw vegetable prices surge by twenty percent last week, thanks to the incessant rains. Tomatoes are selling at rupee eighty per kilogram, up from rupee sixty just a week ago. Onion prices also saw a jump, now retailing at rupees forty per kilogram. A lot of vendors are saying it's because of transportation issues from Nashik.

unnormalised: Local shoppers are feeling the pinch, with many commenting that their monthly budget is going for a toss. "Pehle ₹500 mein sabzi aa jaati thi, ab toh woh bhi mushkil hai," said Mrs. Sharma, a regular shopper at the market. Traders expect prices to remain high for at least 2 weeks, possibly going up by another 10% if the rains continue.
normalised: Local shoppers are feeling the pinch, with many commenting that their monthly budget is going for a toss. "Pehle rupee five hundred mein sabzi aa jaati thi, ab toh woh bhi mushkil hai," said Missus Sharma, a regular shopper at the market. Traders expect prices to remain high for at least two weeks, possibly going up by another ten percent if the rains continue.

unnormalised: Gold rates are also making headlines. Yesterday, 24K gold hit ₹72,000 per 10 grams in Chennai, a record high. Jewellery shops are still seeing brisk business, mainly due to the ongoing wedding season, but many are opting for lighter pieces. Experts predict that if global tensions escalate, gold could touch Rs. 75,000 by end of the quarter.
normalised: Gold rates are also making headlines. Yesterday, twenty four K gold hit rupee seventy two thousand per ten grams in Chennai, a record high. Jewellery shops are still seeing brisk business, mainly due to the ongoing wedding season, but many are opting for lighter pieces. Experts predict that if global tensions escalate, gold could touch rupees seventy five thousand by end of the quarter.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, in Delhi's Sarojini Nagar market, the famous export surplus clothing is seeing increased demand. Kurtis are available from as low as Rs 150/- each and tops are at Rs 200/-, making it a shopper's paradise for budget-conscious college students. "I got 3 tops for just Rs. 600, total steal," exclaimed a Delhi University student.
normalised: Meanwhile, in Delhi's Sarojini Nagar market, the famous export surplus clothing is seeing increased demand. Kurtis are available from as low as rupees one hundred and fifty each and tops are at rupees two hundred, making it a shopper's paradise for budget-conscious college students. "I got three tops for just rupees six hundred, total steal," exclaimed a Delhi University student.

unnormalised: The RBI kept the repo rate unchanged at 6.5% during its latest monetary policy review. This might bring some relief to borrowers, as EMI rates for home and car loans are likely to remain stable, though inflation remains a concern, impacting daily retail prices. The next MPC meeting is scheduled for 06/08/2024, with analysts keenly watching the outcomes.
normalised: The R-B-I kept the repo rate unchanged at six point five percent during its latest monetary policy review. This might bring some relief to borrowers, as E-M-I rates for home and car loans are likely to remain stable, though inflation remains a concern, impacting daily retail prices. The next M-P-C meeting is scheduled for sixth August two thousand and twenty four, with analysts keenly watching the outcomes.
